column1: message
Congratulations! Your project has been awarded $1000 in seed funding. Move forward 2 spaces.
Internal grants are supposed to be easy money. But your project proposal didn’t make the cut. Skip a turn.
"Wow! This is a great idea!" A senior faculty member is excited about your idea and interested in collaborating. Move forward 3 spaces.
"I just don’t get it. Why do this project?" The first senior faculty member you approach isn’t interested in collaborating. Go back 1 space.
You hire a student worker with a skill set perfectly matched to your project. They start working on a prototype. Move forward 3 spaces.
None of the first five student workers you interview are a good match for your project goals. Go back 2 spaces.
"Your project happens to align with some of our goals in the libraries." You start collaborating with a librarian. Move forward 3 spaces.
The first librarian you approach can’t help. "We’re between deans right now and no one knows what our future priorities will be." Go back 2 spaces.
You come up with the perfect name for your project. Move forward 1 space.
You struggle to concisely describe what your project is about and why it matters. Go back 2 spaces.
You and your collaborators are making progress! You start meeting every two weeks. Excitement is high. Move forward 3 spaces.
You and your collaborators fall out of touch. The project is important, but you’re all busy, and there’s so much going on. Skip a turn.
"Multidisciplinary research is the future!" says your chair. Your department encourages your project. Move forward 3 spaces.
Your department is skeptical of your project. "How will we divide credit between all the people involved?" asks your chair. Go back 2 spaces.
You successfully negotiate access to a large, relevant dataset. Move forward 2 spaces.
"We just can’t share this data without violating the terms of our own grant." You have to keep looking for a relevant dataset. Go back 1 space.
"How about we put together a multimedia installation?" It turns out you have a lot in common with an MFA student! Move forward 3 spaces.
"Oh was that due this week?" The MFA student you’re working with prioritized their own work and missed a crucial deadline. Go back 2 spaces.
A Ph.D. student in your department offers a fresh perspective that leads to a breakthrough in how you frame the project. Move forward 2 spaces.
The Ph.D. student you’re working with is struggling to balance course work, their own research, and their project work. Go back 2 spaces
STOP. Your project requires IRB approval because it involves human subject research. Lose two turns while you figure out how to prepare an IRB application.
"Current wait times for IRB review are three weeks and increasing. A reminder that expedited review does not mean your proposal will be reviewed more quickly! Lose a turn.
